subject: Re: [junit] Can anyone help me see how to usefully work with JUnit in a big project, please?
msgSnippet: Hi Cédric, see comments inline. ... I said that the main benifit of TDD is to guide the design, I didn t say that it is the only benefit. I don t know if it
messageBody:
Hi Cédric,
see comments inline.

> > I think, when doing TDD the main benefit is not to find bugs it is to
> > guide
> > your design.
>
> Really?
>
> The main reason why I write tests is to make sure that no regressions will
> happen. From the point where I submit my tests, I know that no matter what
> code gets checked in after me, the functionality of the system will not
> decrease.
>
> Tests also help a great deal make my code more robust.
>
I said that the main benifit of TDD is to guide the design, I didn't
say that it is the only benefit. I don't know if it would be worth
writing unit tests to the extent we do if it "just" shows that things
work and to have a regression suite. Maybe I would suffice with
functional tests then. Who knows?
Remember that TDD is not only about writing the tests, it is also
about refactoring and daring to do that. So by having the benefits
that you speak about that is exacly what you get, courge to change
things (right?) and of course examples to help understanding the
classes they test.

TDD is not only unit tests either, it is also acceptancetests and
integrationtests so not all aspects of TDD occurs on the unit-level
and TDD.

> But drive my design with tests? That's dangerous and can potentially lead to
> micro-design, i.e. design without seeing the big picture ("I'll use this
> signature because the test looks cleaner then").
>

I think that the micro design is also important. Going to and from
there you often find that the larger problems resemble the micro
problems or that the larger problems are easier to solve when you have
a good understanding of the micro problems.
When microdesigning you're doing that for a reason, it has to fit
somewhere in the big picture. I haven't really experienced designing
without seing the big picture. I tend to look at the big picture in
terms of smaller problems that have to be solved in order to get where
I want to go. When I solved one small problem I take a look again at
the big picture to decide where to go next. Not that seldomly with the
new knowledge I've aquired I see things about the big pictire that I
didn't see before and how the big picture shrinks with my newly won
vocabulary (It is funny how big problems can boil down to much fewer
abstractions than you first thought once you start putting your teeth
in it, isnt it?)

It is not forbidden to go to a whiteborad, sketch down UML-diagrams on
a napkin while doing TDD either.

Does that make any sense at all?
